title: 113_s2312
content: The Act is titled the "National Guard Technician Equity Act" and it amends Titles 10 and 32 of the United States Code regarding National Guard Technicians and related provisions. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Titles 10 and 32 of the United States Code to allow non-dual status technicians with 20 years of service to be employed in designated positions. Additionally, an exception to dual-status employment conditions for membership in the Selected Reserve is included. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 10, United States Code, to allow continued compensation for military technicians after loss of membership in the Selected Reserve. It also exempts military technicians from review by Army Qualitative Retention Program or Air Force Selective Retention Program. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 10, United States Code to exempt military technicians from involuntary separation by armed forces retention boards and allows them to re-enlist to maintain eligibility for continued employment. It also repeals permanent limitations on the number of non-dual status technicians. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 10, United States Code to provide technicians with rights of grievance, arbitration, appeal, and review. It also includes provisions for a technician's right of appeal subject to subsection (j) and a labor organization's involvement in the process. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 10, United States Code to provide technicians and labor organizations with rights of grievance, arbitration, appeal, and review for performance-based or adverse actions. The rights extend to the Merit Systems Protection Board and the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. This does not apply to technicians under temporary appointments or in trial periods. The National Guard Technician Equity Act amends Title 10, United States Code to provide technicians with grievance and arbitration rights. It also repeals the prohibition against overtime pay for National Guard technicians under certain conditions. The National Guard Technician Equity Act allows technicians to receive compensatory time off equal to the time spent on irregular or overtime work. SEC. 3 amends Title 5 of the United States Code regarding National Guard technicians and related matters. Section 6323(a) of Title 5, United States Code is amended to allow employees volunteering for active Guard and Reserve duty to not accrue leave. The Secretary of Defense is required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act detailing the average number of hours. The Federal employee who is a member of the National Guard spends a certain number of hours in leave status for training purposes. An assessment is needed to determine if the leave provided is sufficient for National Guard operational tempo. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to report on health care benefits within 180 days. The Comptroller General of the United States will report on the feasibility of converting military technicians from FEHBP coverage to TRICARE Reserve Select during contingency operations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The term "FEHBP coverage" refers to coverage provided under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code.
